message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest Cushing's syndrome. The high urinary free cortisol and low ACTH levels indicate that it is an adrenal gland problem. An abdominal CT can confirm the presence of an adrenal tumor causing the symptoms. CRH stimulation test is used to differentiate pituitary Cushing's disease from other causes, chest CT is used to check for lung cancer that can cause ectopic production of ACTH, and brain MRI is used to check for pituitary adenoma causing Cushing's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results suggest Cushing's syndrome, which can be caused by adrenal tumors or ACTH-secreting pituitary tumors. An abdominal CT scan can help identify the cause by showing evidence of adrenal tumors. The CRH stimulation test is used to distinguish between pituitary and ectopic ACTH production, while a chest CT may be used to look for ectopic tumors. A brain MRI is not likely to be helpful in identifying the cause of the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest Cushing’s syndrome, and imaging is needed to confirm the suspected adrenal tumor. Chest CT is used to screen for lung cancer, but no lung symptoms are reported. Brain MRI is used for pituitary tumors, but the low morning serum ACTH level suggests adrenal tumors. CRH stimulation test can differentiate between pituitary and ectopic ACTH-producing tumors, but in this case, an abdominal CT is more appropriate to confirm the adrenal origin of the tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest Cushing's syndrome, which can be confirmed by an abdominal CT to identify the location of the adrenal tumor. A CRH stimulation test is used to differentiate between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome, which is not indicated in this case. Chest CT and brain MRI are not necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest Cushing syndrome, which can be caused by adrenal or pituitary tumors. An abdominal CT can confirm the presence of an adrenal tumor. The other options are less relevant to the diagnosis of Cushing syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms consistent with Cushing's syndrome, and laboratory studies show elevated urinary free cortisol and low serum ACTH levels. The most likely cause is an adrenal adenoma, which can be confirmed through an abdominal CT scan to identify the presence of a mass on the adrenal gland. A CRH stimulation test is used to differentiate between pituitary and ectopic ACTH production in Cushing's syndrome, but the low ACTH levels make it unlikely that this is the underlying cause. A chest CT and brain MRI would not be useful in identifying the cause of adrenal hypersecretion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggests Cushing Syndrome, which is caused by excess cortisol. The high urinary free cortisol confirms the diagnosis. An abdominal CT is the best test to identify the source of excess cortisol, as it can visualize the adrenal glands and identify any tumors or nodules. CRH stimulation test, chest CT, and brain MRI are not useful in identifying the source of excess cortisol in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest Cushing’s syndrome, which can be caused by an adrenal tumor or ACTH production by a pituitary tumor. Abdominal CT can confirm the presence of an adrenal tumor. Chest CT and brain MRI are not commonly used to diagnose Cushing’s syndrome. CRH stimulation test can be used to differentiate between ACTH-dependent and ACTH-independent causes of Cushing’s syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms and physical exam findings consistent with Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by excess cortisol production. The elevated urinary free cortisol indicates hypercortisolism while the low ACTH level suggests an adrenal source of the excess cortisol. The most likely cause of adrenal hypercortisolism is an adrenal adenoma, which can be confirmed by an abdominal CT scan. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer. A CRH stimulation test is used to distinguish between pituitary and ectopic sources of ACTH, which are less likely in this case. A chest CT or brain MRI are not recommended as the most effective tests to confirm the underlying etiology.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Cushing's syndrome, and the laboratory studies confirm this with elevated cortisol and low ACTH levels. An abdominal CT would be the most appropriate test to confirm the underlying etiology, such as adrenal adenoma or carcinoma. The other options are not indicated for the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome.
